title: German submarine U-569
text:
German submarine "U-569" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She carried out nine patrols, sank one ship of and damaged one other of 4,458 GRT.
She was a member of 15 <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s.
She was attacked by US carrier-borne aircraft from in mid-Atlantic, in May 1943 and surrendered, but was scuttled and abandoned when help arrived.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-569" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">Brown, Boveri & Cie</a> GG UB 720/8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-569" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 21 May 1940 at <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> as yard number 545, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 20 March 1941 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 8 May under the command of "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" Hans-Peter Hinsch.
She served with the <a href="3rd%20U-boat%20Flotilla">3rd U-boat Flotilla</a> from 1 August 1941 for training and stayed with that organization for operations until her loss from 1 August 1941 to 22 May 1943.
First and second patrols.
"U-569"s first patrol was from <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a> in Norway, she headed for the Atlantic Ocean via the <a href="GIUK%20gap">gap</a> separating <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> and the <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe Islands</a>. She arrived at <a href="St.%20Nazaire">St. Nazaire</a> in occupied France, on 21 September 1941.
Having left St. Nazaire on 12 October 1941, "U-569" made for the <a href="Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">Newfoundland and Labrador</a> coast. She returned to her French base on 12 November.
Third patrol.
The submarine was attacked by a <a href="Fairey%20Swordfish">Fairey Swordfish</a> west of <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> on 16 December 1941. She, along with four other U-boats, was to have operated in the Mediterranean, but the damage was such that she had to return to St. Nazaire.
Fourth and fifth patrols.
"U-569" sank the "Hengist" on 8 March 1942 northwest of <a href="Cape%20Wrath">Cape Wrath</a> (Scotland) and returned to France (<a href="La%20Pallice">La Pallice</a>), on 2 April 1942.
On her fifth sortie, she damaged the "Pontypridd" northeast of <a href="St.%20Johns%2C%20Newfoundland">St. Johns, Newfoundland</a>, on 11 June 1942 and took the master prisoner. She returned to La Pallice on the 28th.
Sixth and seventh patrols.
The boat was attacked by the Norwegian corvette HNoMS <a href="Flower-class%20corvette">"Potentilla"</a> on 25 August 1942. The warship lost the element of surprise and her intention to ram when her 4 in gun opened fire prematurely. Several hits were scored on the <a href="conning%20tower">conning tower</a> by 20mm AA guns, but the larger weapon failed to register in the encounter in mid-Atlantic.
The boat's seventh patrol was relatively peaceful with no contacts.
Eighth patrol.
"U-569" was attacked by the escorts of <a href="CU%20convoys">Convoy UC-1</a> on 23 February 1943 and seriously damaged. She had departed La Pallice on 7 February 1943 and returned there on 13 March.
Ninth patrol and loss.
The boat was badly damaged by <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>s dropped by a <a href="TBM%20Avenger">TBM Avenger</a>, piloted by William F. Chamberlain, from the escort carrier on 22 May 1943. A relief Avenger also from USS "Bogue", piloted by Howard S. Roberts, was waiting overhead when the U-boat resurfaced. Roberts dropped more depth charges and machine-gunned the bridge to prevent the German crew from manning the <a href="antiaircraft">antiaircraft</a> guns. U-boat Commander Johannsen had no intention of fighting back and, according to American records ordered his crew to raise a <a href="white%20flag">white flag</a> on the periscope. Upon seeing this, Roberts ceased his attack and guided the Canadian destroyer to the area. As the destroyer approached, Johannsen ordered his crew to scuttle the boat and jump overboard. "St. Laurent" rescued Johannsen and 24 of his crew of 46 and the survivors were sent to Washington for interrogation.
